pros: You quickly realise that you are surrounded by people who are team players, who share a work hard - play hard approach. You are taken a face value, your skill set is valued and your expertise taken heed of. There is room to grow within your role and expand your scope of work in areas that interest you. cons: Sometimes it's necessary to work less regular hours - a longer day here, but balanced by a shorter day there. This never really becomes a problem and is not excessive. The general remuneration is higher in general anyway.

review_title: Don't work here! It's not worth it. Go anywhere else and you will be happier.
pros: I have nothing positive to say.
cons: 1. If you are not Chinese, you will feel excluded. The majority of employees are Chinese, formal communication is in Chinese. I felt like a second class employee during my tenure. 2. My manager did not know how to use a software versioning system. Development with them was a nightmare. Code was being shared through zip files. 3. Most people in management know very little about the mathematics of machine learning. If you communicate what they are saying does not make sense, they will tell you to implement it anyway. When it doesn't work you will get the blame because you did not "debug" it properly. 4. Management tracks your hours not your productivity. 5. Management will shame you in front of other employees instead of giving you feedback in private. There have been instances where my manager rolled their eyes as I was explaining what I was doing. There were times when I was told that management was talking behind my back. 6. You will not receive a GPU enabled device for the first three months of your tenure. There is a very limited GPU server and you will not be able to run your job there. 7. If you talk to the director or human resources, they are not there mediate. 8. As a researcher you have no opportunity to do a literature review and come up with proposal. There is a proposal process, but at the end of the day you end up doing what your manager wants you to do. 9. The research group as a whole is disoriented. It is not known if the goal is to publish or a product. 10. You will have less access to data because of US sanctions. You are better off working in any other company when it comes to data.

review_title: Great employer with lots of challenges
pros: Huawei is a very challenging work environment, innovation and efficiency-driven. The culture is to provide the best to customers, to foster innovation, all together. Initiatives are welcomed, you're given responsibilities and autonomy from the very beginning, so you can work on your projects and join others, and really feel your added-value. The diversity of works is very enriching. There are plenty of topics to work on everyday to keep you stimulated and thanks to which you'll always learn a lot. In addition, the international and multicultural environment makes the work environment even more delightful; people have different stories, cultural and work backgrounds to share, so the daily environment feels very humane. Working at Huawei is not only about enjoying the work or feeling stimulated to provide the best on the market, but it's also about all the different people, different cultures, especially the Chinese culture, the sharing of experiences, the curiosity and to learn from each other.
cons: I can't find any so far.

pros: Very good opportunities. All promotions are done internally - no waiting list or minimum time before trying for a higher position. It all depends on your performance and what you can do to rise above the others. Takes good care of their employees. Once you're in, you can expect to stay with the company for a long time. Haven't heard of unexpected cuts, employees are transferred to other projects rather than fired. If you feel that your current position isn't a good fit for you, they'll help you find one that is. Yearly salary increases, depending on performance, with a yearly bonus (that can go as high as a three-month pay all at once)
cons: Most likely will not be able to join on a non-starter position. Expect to go beyond what is asked of you in order to advance - it will not go unappreciated though

review_title: Huawie India where Challenges turn into Opportunity
pros: This is a dynamic and fast growing MNC, where Performance based culture followed, we get rewarded based on our performance and contribution. Here anyone will grow faster and more rewarded based on their performance and achievement. So if we are hardworking, passionate and having great dedication towards our work and goal, this is right place where we can grab many growth opportunity in dynamic work environment. This is one of the fast growing company who cares customers and it's employee in a great way as a Happy employee create more happy customers. In my last 4 years of work experience I get opportunity in work different type of project and in different country that help me to grow faster and work in different type culture and environment. This company always focus on their Core Values and that is the baseline for all the decision making. review_title: Very good company to start with, maybe to consider a change after 2-3-4 years
pros: Exposure to latest technology, you learn a lot, professional and friendly colleagues, a HUGE chance for fresh graduates, no chance to get bored, a big step for future opportunity in your career (it depends on you). Danish way of work is more relaxed while still result and customer oriented. Sometimes business trips or training outside the country (for some is a Pro for others is a Con but 1-2 weeks of environment and city change is fine for me)
cons: Communication with other departments is quite difficult (need to send many emails, face to face meeting requests); only when the customer gets alerted then things move faster. Feeling of a constant pressure (it can be to not enough resources or bad planning). In some periods, work load is very high (some annual targets) for 1-2-3 months continuously, daily; you feel like you want to quit the job (sometimes no time for lunch) and no extra resources arrangements are made by the management. Salary increase is according to yearly evaluation, company results; mostly the salary you start will be the salary you will keep. You work only with one vendor (general for all vendor companies) so if you want to change company you need to learn the equipment/technology of the other vendor; so no much flexibility in job changing.

review_title: Highly competitive company with result driven culture
pros: Huawei gives you as many chances you are willing to take and throws you challenges you are capable of. In my career of working with 5 MNCs, this company gives you real 360 Deg feedback option to rate your appraiser. Its a common scenario where an engineer with perseverence and good ideas grow to become a program manager or business head in a span of 3 to 4 years. The result being some employees becoming managers of people who were their managers at the beginning. It happens regularly here, where results of indivual is appreciated and rewarded at top of the market compensation. Also i have never seen an employee getting fired on basis of performance without giving him/her considerable amount of changes in different areas to prove themselves. Even then, those cases will be audited and reviewed if its an objective decision by the ethics comittee. Most of all , they respect experienced members no matter the age and dont judget them on basis of 1 or 2 poor year(s). People with experience adapability to environments similar to start-ups and skills to match the role they are in , grow faster here. Politics is least found here, and mostly conducted by very few personalities as its widely condemed here.
cons: 1. Business strategies planned at Head quarters. But over the years its being fedarated. 2. You have be on your toes all the time here grow consitently as its result driven and your last year achievements dont matter. What you are doing now will only matter. So some people will struggle with that notion. 3. Some times communcation gap delays progress of work execution as the company operates in bi-lingual mode with english and chinese used extensively across the board. Lately the IT systems improved drastically to overcome the language gap.

review_title: Dishonest, cheating, deceptive....total SCUM of a company
pros: You come out stronger after facing off an army of dishonest and incompetent fools.
cons: Where do I begin? When I first told people I was going to work for a Chinese tech company, many in my circle advised me against it. At first, I felt it was not fair and maybe a little racist. But after 3.5 years there, now I know better: its not about what they look like or what language they speak or what food they eat. Its about what they do. This company is devoted to cheating, lying and deceiving people in the quest to acquire technology. Just 2 years ago or so, there was a lawsuit against Huawei by a former employee in Canada who said in a news article that Huawei was a vast intelligence operation. Based on what I saw and experiened, I feel this is true. Huawei has almost 30 "research" centers all over the world where their "research" just involves sourcing technology by any means possible. In the project I was in, they shipped a certain component that was export controlled and not meant for exporting to China by declaring an exemption themselves! They did it 3 times! I was twice asked to do something questionable and probably illegal but I declined. The company has rules on paper against such activities but well its just paper. I have never seen a culture so corrupt and full of deceit. What makes it worse is that, they abuse the hospitality of their host countries and slowly turn some of their non-Chinese employees to do things their way because employees are rewarded for their "contributions". I was not involved in 5G and I don't know anything about the CEO's daughter but I don't trust this company and would be the least surprised if accusations against her come out to be true, based on what I saw and experienced. Another interesting fact: I have been monitoring Glassdoor reviews for this company from years ago and I know for a fact that there were many negative reviews here and new reviews were not incoming - the reviews were stagnant for quite some time but then all of a sudden, I see some positive 1 liner reviews. These are all fake, trust me. What some of the older reviews say: "Huawei is only interested in your former employer's IP" etc are all so true. This company exists to cheat and its employees behave as if its their daily job - find a new way of acquiring technology and when they do, they rub their hands in glee thinking how smart they are. This is not a company where an engineer can make a career. The CEO Reng Zhengfei is the biggest cheerleader I know. He gives the most amazing, good-to-hear speeches but all are fake. Once he said in a BBC news article that Huawei doesnt need to spy since it has 90,000 engineers but he omitted the fact that these are not 90,0000 engineers but 90,000 incompetent imbeciles who rely on research centres abroad to feed them with technology acquired via questionable means. There is not a single new Chinese tech that is totally indigenous. I also met at least 2 employees in Huawei China that were ex-military so I am also inclined to believe what the US is saying. The non-local employees and managers from HQ try to act friendly with local staff but well role play is role play. There are many telltale signs giving them away when they try to convince you to "collaborate" with your former or other companies. At the end of day, we must keep in mind that this is not a British or German or Japanese or American company that has some decency. In all, I decided that my years there were not a total waste since I got to know what a scum company looks and operates like. I will take it as a good lesson learned. In summary, Huawei's research centers are not for research. They are just there to poach employees from rival companies.

review_title: Great Place to Develop Your Career
cons:
ant opportunities within the company that allow for both personal and professional development. Huawei focuses heavily on it's employees providing all sorts of training, activities and mentorship which bolster key traits whether you have just graduated or are a senior professional. Huawei rewards employees on performance and value brought to the company making it easy to rise through the ranks if you do well.
Cons
There will most likely be a language and culture barrier in the beginning. New employees might not be able to immediately deal with the high pressure, as the company is heavily based on results.

pros: Although I have been here for a few months only, I have seen quite a few positive things so far: Opportunities to create products that are used by millions Opportunities to develop expertise in key technological areas Contrary to other big tech firms, where most of the high end work happens in US, you get to do the high end work in India office at Huawei A large pool of talented peers to engage with and learn from Supportive management. Your ideas are listened to and acted upon
cons: Sometimes things can be a bit too much process/approvals driven. This is actually a good thing for customer security but people joining from other tech companies may take a few days to get used to it

pros: I joined Huawei as a Project Manager in September 2019 after a competitive selection procedure, through the companyâ€™s graduate scheme. I am currently based in the companyâ€™s head offices in the UK, in Reading. I assumed several responsibilities from day one while at the same time I embarked on a well-planned induction and training programme that involved training in Reading, Birmingham, Dusseldorf, Milan. Unfortunately missed out on Madrid due to the onset of Covid-19. I had close mentoring, guidance, and feedback throughout my employment which I found very practical and constructive and at the same time, as a programmer, I was encouraged and actually proposed ideas and improvements in areas where I had more advanced skills. Although the business environment is generally pleasant and flexible, the fast pace of the high tech industry requires lots of reserves of stamina, resolve, and determination. There is an opportunity to work and share experiences with other professionals in Reading and abroad. Good working conditions, sports teams that everyone is welcomed to join, quite decent restaurant especially if you are a fan of spicy Chinese cuisine, and organisation of various events. Chinese New Yearâ€™s party not to be missed.
cons: Nothing of importance so far.

review_title: Great company to make you better
pros: Good pay, great coworkers, getting professional skills and experience efficiently
cons: Tough management, over time work

pros: - Lots of resources available nowadays to do projects with. - Generally longer term outlook than a lot of other companies. - Some very good and highly smart colleagues to work with. - The good managers will listen to the merits of competent technical arguments. - Solid pay and reasonable benefits. - If you work hard and get results that lead to good performance reviews, you will often be rewarded.
cons: - Culture is very "Chinese". And the "wolf culture" can create an unfriendly and competitive atmosphere. - Non-fluency in Mandarin limits opportunities for growth and promotion, and separates you from the insiders. - Overtime is expected when necessary and work/life balance is not a priority. - Lack of trust from HQ, and lots of greyness and uncertainty in terms of feedback about progress and projects. - External geopolitical stuff is a distraction that can add pressure to the work environment as well as outside social relationships with non-ex-pats. - Bureaucratic systems can be confusing to navigate and understand.

pros: Continuous learning and challenge projects to take on, Very Good work environment, Good employees engagements,

pros: A great passport to get to another non Chinese technology company.
cons: Treatment to whoever that is not Chinese is very bad. 1. They will hire you through a outsourcing company (manpower) for most Latin American countries, give you all the responsibilities of any position but the whole credit for any achievement will always be for your Chinese boss which will be able to move to a better position after one or two years. 2. No matter how many experience you have and how good you are doing your work, they will always make sure to send a Chinese guy from another office, city or even continent to be your supervisor. Even if you are lucky enough to be taken into account for a director position. 3. Serious meetings will always be a Chinese secret, usually done during the night (from 9:00pm and forward) to make sure that nobody from the local team can support or give any ideas. 4. Staying late and doing overtime (without getting paid) will be a plus during your stay in Huawei. It doesn't really matter if you stay late in the office playing candy crush or watching YouTube videos. You will only be a good asset to the company if you stay late, they say that it is a "Cultural thing". 5. Medical insurance, supermarket expenses, yearly bonus, share ownership will only be granted to you if you are a "Chinese staff". 6. Since your boss will be a Chinese guy, he won't have any idea about the working law for your country. 7. Feedback, couching, and career development does not exist. 8. One of the most common forms to get your Huawei "staff" promotion is getting very close to Chinese managers, this means, letting them know where the strip clubs are located in your country, going to casino with them (they love those ones), introduce them to some local girls, having good breasts, etc.

pros: * Lot of work, if you're lucky you'll get assigned to some good projects. * If you're an extreme workaholic, then Huawei may be a good place for you. * Good bonus (depends on how good you lick your manager's boots though, still decent enough)
cons: * Lots of firing after US-China trade war. They are not even giving compensation to the employees who are getting fired. They forcefully ask the employees to resign by sending mail that "Due to personal reasons I'm resigning." * Too much work. You'll literally have no work life balance. I've never seen sunset after joining there. * Managers are the worst which you can find in the industry. They don't plan anything and all they know is to keep putting pressure on the developers to work work and work. * Though few teams work on some good technologies, many teams don't work on good technologies. Most of the good work will be taken by China and India will be doing all the crap work. * Indian managers are mainly puppets who'll listen to Chinese people and play the fool around. They accept whatever that comes from China. * Cafeteria is closed by 9.30 in the morning. So that employees don't "waste" their time having breakfast and they'll "utilize" in working and making it "productive". Same in the afternoon. * You'll have 1.5 Paid Leaves every month. But please keep in mind that you'll not need those since you'll not be granted leaves only. * As usual, lots of team politics (This is pretty common in many companies as I can't say as a con for Huawei alone) * If you complete your work in 12-13 hours and leave you'll not be respected, but even if you don't complete your work, but stay in office sitting here and there for 16+ hours, you'll have some respect (At least in the department which I've worked. They feel number of hours put in work = Efficiency )

review_title: A local paradise at Russian Research Center
pros: Huawei has established a strategic plan to build strong R&D in Russia and to expand it by many times compared to the previous scale. The old (1999-2019) Huawei R&D in Russia and the new one (2019+) are completely different stories. The latter is being built in Google-like style with flexible schedules and A-class new offices. Huawei adopts the best practices to enable Russian employees to work in their localized style without direct translation of the Chinese rules like is was before. Given the big package size Huawei can offer to talented engineers, it is now one of the best employers in Russia in the ICT field.
cons: Some Chinese colleagues from HQ speak English not fluently. But if you have a strong local leader it's not a problem for engineers.

review_title: International mindset and full of opportunities and responsabilities
pros: Working in Huawei means working with colleagues from all around the world. You can make a meeting with some Chinese colleagues one hour, and then switch to India, Turkey and Romania after 30 minutes, plus all the Italian meetings with the clients. Most of the projects have real impacts on final subscribers (whether it is 5G, optic fiber or some business critical software) and hence it is easy to find the right motivation to perform at your best. In 2 years I have increased step-by-step my responsibilities and I am now managing a team, always working at the client-office to make possible all the requirements.
cons: Flexible mindset required. There are many experts, both a lot of times you can interact with them just from remote and sometimes it is more demanding to overcome all the language and culture differences.

review_title: Come here if you want to be humiliated
pros: Very high salary, nice building
cons: Lack of trust from the managers Lack of merits recognition Since I've been here, all my concepts have been basically stolen and converted into very low-quality strategies (which, ironically, received high praises from the Chinese superiors) If you're not Chinese, you're basically just a piece of meat for them. YOU DON'T MATTER in their eyes Whatever you say or advice against all their courses of actions, they won't matter (even if you're very skilled in your area). The Chinese managers, although very inexperienced in the domain they manage, always know better. Shady salary raises Chinese managers have the worst level of English I've ever experienced so far. What's worse is that every highly important e-mail is written in Chinese, even though 90% of the mail participants are English speakers. The Chinese managers also report fake growth numbers in their project and always get away with it The work - life balance is also bad High discrimination towards the non-Chinese employees Stiff clocking in and out procedure I'm only staying here for the money. Honestly, I'm surprised at how long I succeeded to stay in this company, despite all the accumulated frustrations...

pros: They have deep pockets and are willing to consider ambitious research agenda. Free parking
cons: Where do I start? This is a totally Chinese company. as opposed to an international one. Here is what is wrong with it: 1. Boss is always right in the eastern culture and you notice that in all discussions and meetings. My boss's contribution to the discussions was minimal as he did not know anything about our project and he would not take the time to educate himself. 2. Non mandarin speaking people are second level employees. They are not consulted on anything . They have no idea about the discussions, project plans, etc. In our group, mandarin speaking employees would meet every day for hours and we had no idea what the discussion was about even though it would impact us directly. Most of the times, in the meetings, people start speaking mandarin for no reason without regard for the rest of the attendees. Very rude and disrespectful. They do not mingle with the rest of the employees and make you feel not welcome. 3. No transparency. In this culture, transparency is not valued and you are ALWAYS kept in the dark. 4. There are different standards for work place etiquette in Huawei. There are multiple signs about not spitting in the kitchen sink, not dirtying the washrooms, etc. 5. There is no diversity or respect for other cultures. It's all about the Chinese culture. In my estimate 70% + of the employees are Chinese. 6. CHAOS, CHAOS CHAOS: We did not have projects for more than a year. Everyday our boss would make up stories about the great projects we will be starting VERY soon. He would ask us to create powerpoints that no one would read and no one would give feedback because you are not part of the clique of mandarin speaking employees.. Be ready to waste your time for a year or two without having any actual work. Imagine what happens to your resume when you have nothing to show. 7. Promotions: Be ready to see a junior employee (education, work experience and history in the company) to become your boss very soon. Back to #1. Most managers are there because they speak mandarin. 8. This job located is in Markham. You have to drive everywhere and there is no diversity like the rest of the Toronto. I did not like Markham at all.

review_title: Not the Multinational Company that They Promote ... More a Chinese Company Overseas
pros: - Great Salaries (ONLY If you come from the competitors and have senior or more experience). - Bonuses (ONLY for staff ... and they are not really hiring directly some time ago) - If you are a freshman you can have a great time learning a lot about many technologies but don't expect great training by the company even if they send you to China. Most of the products knowledge you'll have to learn it by yourself. - If you are young is a good place to work but MOVE FAST to a next position.
cons: - Bad salaries if you are a freshman or almost non existent raises for long term employees. - Sales are blocked mainly because Huawei, not because competition or customers. Sometimes you have to explain two or three times the things to your chinese counterpart to convince him about almost anything (status of a project, opportunities, customer relationship) - The company internally is like two companies in one. One with the locals and the other with Chinese. Nowadays all crucial decisions are made exclusively by Chinese Managers; 100% those managers doesn't know a thing about the country they are, the language or the business culture and even worse most of them are just unexperienced even on management positions they are holding (I saw a new product manager for the whole carrier core network coming to the country with only programming experience and being younger and unexperienced than the whole engineer division under him). - The company is ruled by business culture that no one ... absolutely no one is unexpendable. They don't care to fired good employees or account managers with really good relationships with customers (and even lose those). - Be careful with the contracts, bonuses and extras they promise to you on your contract. I saw multiple times they reduced the final salary of managers or product specialist that came from the competition. Some colleagues got outsourcing contracts instead of direct contract without warning or even they got reduced salaries than what was offered in the selection process. Many of them just got bored and annoyed by the company in less than 9 months of being there. - Many bonuses are not as high as they promote to you or even some chinese employees got part in them without doing anything ... literally anything on the projects. A collegue got promised a raise, a big bonus and change of his contract after closing a big project (it got awarded) and he was fired. Be careful if you are looking for a commercial career here.

review_title: Not for everyone but great pay and experience,
pros: Engineers at Huawei are world class builders and are very open and passionate about new technical ideas. Cutting edge technology is easy to get experience with if you have ambition and a curious mind. You can travel to China and many other countries, and learn every step of the way. Huawei's pay is higher than market rates, typically significantly so. US workers perform advanced development and do not undergo the same treadmill-like lifestyle found in many other software shops. In short, it can be a unique opportunity for someone with an open mind, and for those who like to invent.
cons: The company has been singled out by the US government as a bad actor, although no evidence of "backdoors" has been produced as of yet. This stigma is annoying. People used to a highly organized "scrum" culture, or who are not self motivated, will probably be unhappy. People who cannot work well with other cultures probably would be a bad fit.

pros: Good environment and good life-work balance

pros: The only pro is they pay much higher than most companies in Silicon Valley, especially in terms of base salary. Also, there is the chance of traveling to China.
cons: -Gave me very little information before joining and mislead me quite a bit. Said I working with certain people but it turned out not to be true. I met very few people before joining. -Give me no work after joining no matter how much I ask for work. Some people seem to have way too much work and some way too little. Management is very passive. For things that are critical they tell employees to get it done and they don't care at all how it gets done(i.e. they are not involved technically). For things that are not critical they expect employees to be super active and get amazing stuff done without having to spend any of their own effort. -Everyone is very political and nobody works together with a common goal. Everything is centrally controlled from China and you can't see the organization chart in China, only the US. It is very unclear what the management structure is. Most people will have multiple managers, some in the US and some in China. -A lot of brainwashing by the HR team during their orientation. They play lots of videos and try to hypnotize you into thinking you are saving the world. They make you accept a book that was published by some executives and I'm suprised they don't force you to read it out loud. -They are paranoid about information security and have lots of restrictions which make it impossible to get anything done at work. The management tells us to violate some of the company policies in order be able to get at least some stuff done and the IT people turn a blind eye to this. People are constantly getting in trouble for violating some company policy. -Almost all of the important information for doing engineering work is located in China so it's almost impossible to get anything done in the US. All of the decision making is made there. -There is no socializing at our company and it's very racially segregated. -Managers are very non-technical and the skill level of most employees is low. -During the process of setting personals goals for the year for which we will be evaluated there was no interaction with management besides extremely vague statements about what they wanted me to accomplish. When I tried to get clarification I was blown off. -The company strategy is to just hire very experienced senior engineers in the US with more than 15yrs experience and milk them for knowledge. HR and management don't try to hide this at all. They are not interested in having a permanent presence in the US and developing the younger generation here. Huawei employs about 180,000 people. They are constanty shifting around what people do in China so the people there are not experts at anything. -The English skills of many of the people in the US and most people in China are very poor. The communication style is also very indirect. The good thing is the people in the US make a honest effort to communicate well(sometimes it's still not good enough though). However, the bad thing is many people in China will not respond to numerous emails you send them. There is no spirit of working towards a common goal with them. -Nobody on my project seems to care about doing a good job. No matter how active I tried to be to promote good ideas and directions nobody responds to you at all. It shows the attitude of the people there.

pros: - nice and big office - has shuttle services to transport you from one office to another - IF you can speak Chinese, it's a plus - IF you are mainland Chinese, you'll have more benefits like meals, accommodation, housing allowance, etc - Salary is actually good enough, and they have quarterly bonuses and cash vouchers which depends on your performance - Dealing with approvals and documents are convenient since everything is done systematically
cons: - difficult to climb the corporate ladder if you're a local, because they prioritize Chinese - if you get a technical job, expect you're gonna have overtime on most days, but for me, I don't. - for local hires, you will be hired under an agency and will have a different benefit package from the Chinese, so you're not really direct hire - no language premium for Chinese speaking locals - If you are local, there's no growth for you, HR doesn't really value their local employees, unless you are senior hire - Dealing with the Chinese employees here can be hard; language barrier, work ethics, attitude and etiquette (some people). Very demanding and pushy when it comes to work

ltant in Stockholm, Stockholm, Stockholm
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Must be the most unorthodox -non-swedish company to work for in Sweden. Salary is high in comparison (otherwise nobody would work for them) High tempo, intense, every day can be different Gives a feeling that if you can succeed here, you can succeed anywhere Chain of command can be hectic and conflictuous (relationship-based and not process-based)
Cons
As non-swedish as it gets; Crazy work style, relationship-based. There is not a company directory, and even if it existed one, chinese won't reply to you if they don't know who you are or they are not ordered to talk to you (again, the relationship based-workflow) Only chinese in higher positions (if you see a "westerner" there, it is just for show, no real power)

review_title: Huge distance between Huawei culture and European culture
pros: The salary, if you stay long within the company, will be higher compared to the competition
cons: Very hierarchical - top down management Cannot criticise or give feedback on decisions made by (sr) management You are expected to work 50 - 60 hours and sacrifice a lot for the company Lack of access to information if you are not Chineze. review_title: Huawei Technologies R&D Belgium nv in Leuven: crazy working conditions..
pros: salary slightly better than average, high technical level or supposed so. Supposedly , improves your technical skills but you might need time to digest high complexity. Leuven is clean city much cleaner than brussel.
cons: It used to be a nice place where to work formelly named M4S, since then most of the founders have quited 1 or 2 years after it becames Huawei Technologies R&D Belgium nv. Later, just like in IMEC the management is beeing maintained under flemish control. Basically, in this new satelite branch of huawei you are squeezed like a lemon just like with chineses in china absolutely no work-life balance whatsoever !! The management is anyway very very centralized, the local flemish managers do what they are told to do and they add an authentic tough and harsh flemish management style much appreciated by the chinese and that's why they are kept in their position. 1. There is no possibility to discuss the overwhelming workload (for instance 3 tape out at the same time) because anyway in changhai they work so hard and even on saturday. btw, your boss may call you on sunday to work if necessary, make sure to be reachable. 2. People are so stressed and tired that they could even become ill, this was true even for a chinese girl in shanghai ( she quit job) and an indian lady. Of course, this will be denyed and covered not to damage the huawei brand. 3a. Specfications can change at anytime, sometimes you have the feeling that they don't know exactly what they want. Even worse, the team competing with your group in shanghai knows the spec change before the team your belong to. 3b. if you're a project manager, you are not forgiven if you did not cope for the change in specs. The punishment can be as scornful as not invited to show for groupe picture to be sent to huawei central management. 4. Huawei claim that the company belongs to the employee, however, If you are not chinese, you cannot have shares in the company which is quite unfair. 5. if you have a made a technical mistake your name and picture might be shown somehere in shanghai, the chinese way to punish people. anyway your name is in a kind of blacklist. 6. If you are a designer or layouter probably if you want to stay in huawei leuven, you might be senior but that's it you stay in your field and you probably cannot be part of the management unless you're flemish. 7. awful cantine/ it rains almost every day in winter/renting a decent flat in leuven is costly. At the time of writing this, at least 6 people have a left Huawei Technologies R&D Belgium nv in less than a year.

review_title: Few pros but lots of important cons
pros: Last time I checked you could use the Chinese restaurant for breakfast, lunch and dinner. This is a big bonus as this workplace may be the only place in Istanbul where you can enjoy the most authentic Chinese food. And it has definitely a very high value to price ratio. You can meet and work together with young and ambitious colleagues who are currently enrolled in graduate programs.
cons: Managers are not experts in their assigned projects, even more they do not seem to be interested in developing their skills. People with already acquired research and project management skills are ignored and not acknowledged for no good reason. You are assessed for your so-called "performance" every six months. However, this is not analytical as the requirements set are vague and change very often during the term. You are not given clear objectives that you can tackle, thus your assessment correlates with your closeness with your manager and whether she/he likes you or not.

review_title: Unprofessional , unequal workplace, but growing company
pros: Huawei is a Chinese fastgrowing company with international presence and a success story in telco network equipments, where it became the marketleader by first underpinning prices of competitors at any cost, secondly by relentless servility towards customers and thirdly, by finally also becoming a producer of well-engineered hardware. The company 's most recent success story as manufacturer of highend smart devices further boosted growth and earned more awareness for the company's brand. Definitely has a good growth perspective, and also provides growth for employees- if and only if you are mainland Chinese. For Westerners the salaries are generally good, and if you are lucky, you may get a bonus. Chinese persons can get absolutely huge bonuses, so this is a great place for Chinese to work. The technology and the products are often exciting and the growth story is amazing.
cons: Sadly, Huawei is a place that has no viable work culture for European or US people. Moreover, it openly favors Chinese managers and employees over other nations, in development, bonuses and simply in every aspect of work. Western people never can exercise any influence, never be trusted and never be equal to Chinese, no matter the knowledge, the performance or loyalty. Western people are simple tools to service Chinese, any Chinese actually. It is actually amazing that this totally unequal-opportunities employer is allowed to function legally in Europe. Information and communication is often Chinese first, sometimes in Chinese only. The work culture is averse to logical or advance planning, plans are never valid for long and no one cares. The company is highly-highly hierarchic, resents open discussions and change, bottom up innovation or proactivity is frown upon and not desired. Managers are 95% Chinese , and many of them are thrown into positions and markets they have zero knowledge about, as part of expat policy for Chinese at Huawei. In 2-3 years, By the time the manager actually understands and becomes more able to perform the job, he is made to leave for a next assignment. The mentality is military-oriented: do not think just execute anything on order. If there is no superior who gives an order, nothing happens, business can rot, no one cares. is lats-minute everything, and due to,this and due to lack of understanding customers and markets, actions are often desperate actions, hence stress levels are often high. The technology is exciting, the products can be often proud of and salary may be good for Westerners, but the daily irrationality, the fact to be just a tool,or best a tolerated 2nd rate employee, the lack of equal chance to grow as a person, the total lack of respect or appreciation by management goes against the heart and head of every decent Western person..., sooner or later you feel that your capabilities are fading, your soul and passion is being killed and ultimately, you end up frustrated and shrinking.

review_title: Not a fun place to work
pros: Huawei is a highly successful company that has come to dominate the telecoms infrastructure industry in a few short years. It offers high quality, innovative products and invests heavily in R&D. Huwei has simply out competed Ericsson and Nokia by first undercutting them and then out engineering them. The company invests hugely in engineering, but is no particularly creative or innovative.
cons: Huawei is not a good work environment for the Western workforce. It is a Chinese company with some international presence. Westerners are tolerated at best. No Westerner can have any real authority or influence. Westerners aren't really trusted and the cultural expectations of a Western workforce are barely acknowledged by Chinese Management. The organization is hugely hierarchical and fast-track managers are often catapulted into roles that they have no understanding of and no real ability in. Decision making is highly centralised, as are budgets. Forward planning and reasonable treatment of employees is rare. The companies Personal Business Objectives drive a lack of cooperation and "big picture" thinking. People focus purely on their personal business objectives and the financial rewards they bring (and the rewards can be huge) without any real analysis of whether they are the "right" things to do. This all contributes to a highly unpleasant atmosphere. Knee-jerk reactions, last-minute decision making, lack of consultation and micro-management. Huawei pays well, but you sell your soul, and no (Western) employees really enjoy the company.

pros: - Racism towards local employees: There is no trust between Chinese employees and the local, some meetings are organized only between Chinese. I have been working on projects in which the local colleagues were not aware of the development of the project because the Chinese colleagues would not include them in the email exchanges. - Heavy processes: There is a process for everything, sometimes only in Chinese. The request has to be explained again and again to N+1 level... It's time and energy consuming... - No balance between private and professional life: Some departments are in the office on Saturday, trainings are organized during the weekend and as many say in the company: â€œOvertime is the culture of Huawei". - Poor language skills: English is said to be the official working language of the company; however, the level of English is extremely poor, processes and emails are only available in Chinese from a certain level. In the high management, some are unable to speak French, Dutch, and their English is so poor, sometimes even impossible to understand. - Poor management skills: The new management team is worryingâ€¦ I had to explain how to manage project to my managerâ€¦ Everything was urgent and last minute. For example, that meeting that was organized at 17.00 from 18.00 to 22.00 on a Friday. - Worthless values: They are written everywhere in the office, but you wonâ€™t experience themâ€¦ Except for one: customer first (after the CEO though). Respect is non-existing and â€œthank youâ€ is rare. There is no space for openness nor initiative, you have to follow the process. I wonâ€™t even talk about integrity. As of team work, it applies only between locals or between Chinese. Huaweiâ€™s HR strategy is quite superficial: if you want to leave, they will offer a raise; if you are reluctant to join, they will offer a â€œgood salaryâ€.
cons: + Colleagues: I have met wonderful colleagues and created good friendships. I still see some of them and it is always a pleasure to have a small drink with them!

review_title: Bad Culture - Overworked Sad People - Horrible place to Work
pros: Big brand name: Leading Global 500 Fortune ICT company - for now. High pay to lure people in dead-end jobs. None really.
cons: No work life balance. Calls at midnight, weekends, annual leaves, at hospitals. Expected to work 24/7 as human robot. No respect to human rights, employee rights and work/life balance. What's worse, it's normal to many Huawei employees to call you at hospital bed, or your childrenâ€™s birthday party, they expect you to come office. Bad culture. Company culture is based on Army culture: rules, regulations, violations, punishments. Locals are treated as second class employee aka slaves, never promoted to key C-level positions. Your position will be replaced with Chinese or a new Local at any given time. Firing is the easiest act in Huawei. Profits before people. Stolen hardwork. You will be asked to do other people (chinese) jobs, but not paid or graded for it. Then, you see Chinese get awards, promotions, salary increases for your hard-work. Because of bad company culture, bad reputation in the market if you work at Huawei. Not recommend anyone to work here. Unless you want to be in Chinese prison for many years, until you get better offer from another company.

pros: Great company to work and learn , I have been working for Huawei for long time Technology is good , you will get lot of learning experience and learn responsibility of each task , ownership and quality of work is very important , company is focused on customer value and quality of each product

pros: 1. Fast track career growth - Highly performance driven organization. Work contributions gets recognized. People with exceptional abilities and contribution grow very very fast. 2. Higher Compensation - The Company is in Bangalore not because of cost advantage, but to leverage quality resources and software eco system available locally. They don't shy paying a Tier-1 MNC salary. Company's yearly bonus and stock dividends are very generous and directly proportional to companies profit and revenue. Huawei is a privately owned company by its employees. So good share from the profit earned by company is passed to employees as Bonus, Stock dividend and hikes. 3. Challenging work assignments - You work in product and solutions R&D in ICT domain. Company is very aggressive and positions its product very competitive in market in terms of product features, performance etc. So you get to work on challenging problems most of the time. 4. Chance to work in diverse technologies from Telecom to Cloud, Bigdata, consumer devices etc - Company has diversified portfolio .Has 4 BGs in different Industry segments, and all 4 have R&D teams in India - i. Carrier (Telecom), ii. Enterprise, iii.
cons:
mer (smartphones+other devices) and iv. Cloud. It is easier to move across technologies and domains as long as you have proven/contributed to your current project. Quality of work has never been a concern here. 5. Strong culture, centered around its core values-Customer centricity, Dedication and Self-reflection. This is Huawei's strength and differentiates itself with other MNCs. The orientation of employees towards the company's core value and culture is pretty strong. Most people here are aligned to company's global values and you would find many employees working with the company for more than 10-15 years.
Cons
1. Lower work efficiency due to Communication difficulty with head quarters - Due to language barrier and remote location (from HQ), some times information flow is not consistent. 2. No work from home option. However I see that in recent past, company is more open to acknolowledge this as an issue and providing some flexibility for certain type of work like open source based projects.

pros: I enjoyed my time at Huawei. The company is definitely a place for young and budding people who aspire for a challenge and are willing to jump in and experience the fast-paced atmosphere. I just spent almost years at Huawei and its been worth the time. The company is young and still growing very fast. Its easy to compare it to already established companies and criticise it but Huawei as I joined it several years ago has come a long way and I believe the future looks bright. The salaries are not bad compared to market average and with a very diverse staff. Mostly Chinese from HQ but I have noticed that this has gradually reduced with the passing years .
cons: Management needs to eventually ease their foot on the "Home-Office" topic and continue with the localization programme, enhancing more local participation in managing the company and also showing more and more trust to our local staff.and employer branding activities . The company can become even more international if we learn to share the authority and trust the non-Chinese to hold top positions and still deliver. I know the company is at this stage where this is being given more and more attention. The future looks bright.

pros: 1) It is performance driven environment and the members contributing consistently high have very good opportunity of moving to next higher role / diverse role. Also, they have chance to get promoted to next level designation faster than the normal performers. This has given high motivation to many. 2) Huawei encourages all the members to have E2E understanding - Requirements to Deployment, this makes their work link with the Final result and how each task can be aligned to the Final End result. This enables member to have higher exposure and this also helps them make projects success and move the roles. 3) Huawei encourages consistent high contributing experienced members to move from one domain other domain, to give them exposure and groom them to next higher roles.
cons: Sometimes there could be some unhealthy competition

pros: You get a lot of exposure to new Tech systems and a lot of documentation. So if learning is really your thing this could be the place for you.

review_title: Huawei Graduate Program - A Missed Opportunity
pros: - Professional experience in one of the worlds largest technology companies - Personal experience dealing with different culture. It toughens you up. - Great stepping stone for other jobs. - Will probably be a highlight on your CV for the next 10 years (if the company continues to grow as it is). - Good work life balance (I was lucky).
cons: I can only comment on my version of the Graduate Program, which I'm told is constantly (although slowly) improving: - Terribly disorganized Graduate Program which is not adapted to local market. - Backwards management style. - Not a good place to start your career, as skills and techniques are usually not translatable (I found my next job by learning most skills outside of the office). - Down to luck whether you are completely overworked, if your project is decent and/or if your manager is western-friendly. - Very Chinese-centric and extremely bureaucratic.

pros: Very good pay and benifits

review_title: Huawei India R&D - Customer Centric work Culture
pros: 1. I am working in Huawei India R&D 15+ years now. Huawei India R&D involved in many High technology areas such as Cloud, Big Data, Mobile/
cons:
mer products, IOT, DB, Open Source, Storage, IT, OSS, Platform Middleware and VAS domain. 2. Major aim is to focus on customer requirement and use high end technology to ensure customer success. There is an unique award called "Future Stars" which is democratically choosen by peers. 5. One very postive aspects of Huawei is, it provides opportunities to people in different areas depending on their strengths. This helps people to have a better career plan.
Cons
1. Expectations are high. One need to always focus on high contributions, constantly upgrade his/her skills. Sometime, people are not comfortable to do it.

pros: Exposure to a pure China-based company. Understanding different cultures is always positive Above-average pay for the position, above average bonuses assuming you perform well
cons: Toxic Culture Yelling matches in the office considered normal. Managers openly yell at customers and then wonder why we lose out on projects Managers are consistently late or in some cases don't show up for meetings and give no prior notice. They then proceed to yell at you if you show up 5 minutes late because a previous meeting went over and they didn't see your IM stating that you would be late. Of course, no apology was given. Long working hours resulting from over bureaucratic processes and broken English. Local offices have relatively little authority to make decisions and as a result there is a lot of reporting and approvals required. Nothing wrong with that. But why do I have to fill out the same information across 5 forms and STILL have to talk to the "guy" in China for approval? Three-quarters of my time was wasted on paperwork and seeking approvals. The official working language was touted as English, yet documents were not translated by native speakers or professionals. As a result, this created a lot of communication issues. Presentation materials often had to be re-done as there were serious formatting, grammar and spelling issues. Discriminatory promotion practices - It was an open secret that only people from China could hold management positions

review_title: Chinese Expats over Local Aussies/Chinese/Non-Chinese - Stay away!
pros: Salary package is above average compared with the industry You may get a great boss who fights for the employees but it's pretty rare
cons: Chinese only meetings happen frequently with the exclusion of local Aussie/non Chinese employees. Enterprise department seem to have a shot gun method on bidding for every single bid rather than bid for tenders/projects that are realistically probable to win and meet the potential customer's needs. HR department are very much aligned to the HQ and mass exodus happened at the end of 2017. Carrier department seems to have swapped out most of the local Aussies with obedient Chinese cheaper expats. The toilets are filthy and HR have been given that feedback with inaction. American adopted "hire and fire" style as required by projects. Most of the 680 employees are on fixed contract to meet this style. Even working for many Aussie/western companies, i see lot more office underground extra marital affairs in this work place than any other I have worked in. Across the company chinese expats can't even speak properly English to engage with local customers. I was shocked to find out they were hard selling from the on set in broken English without any aussie cultural awareness.

pros: The experience and knowledge I gained.
cons: The Salary is to low.

pros: 1. Company (Chinese personnel) do not care about you at all. You are only a tool for them. It is completely not important what you know, what experience you have, what you can improve. The only important thing what you can delivery in particular moment when Chinese asking about it. More, if you know that their idea is wrong, you cannot improve that because you will be first enemy. 2. Huawei has not management layer. Here is army style commanding. Commander (i.e. your manager, his manager, VP or anybody in charge) has always right. There is nothing special that one day you must go on left feet and on another day left is forbidden. There is not â€˜mind stormâ€™. Instead of this is committee management style. It looks like as many Chinese employee are sitting together in a meeting room and they are discussing about any issue or decision to make (even simplest one) for 1,2 or 3h. Finally, most important of them telling everybody that they must forward this topic to HQ in China to get approval. Usually HQ adding another 1-2 weeks to decision process. 3. You are not allowed to communicate with Customers or Subcontractors. All communication must be canalized by Chinese account manager or procurement team. 4. Everybody at Huawei are not sharing any knowledge. There is not technical documentation in English or if you will find some, it is outdated. Any right documentation is in Chinese and you have no permission to read it. 5. You are permanently watched â€“ by CCTV in the office, by special web filters in computer, by key loggers and by special dedicated security cell in the office which connect to your desktop on PC to verify that you are work properly. 6. If you are a â€˜core team memberâ€™ in a project, you as non-Chinese member will not get any bonuses or this bonus will be very small (according to bonus budget for a core team members) 7. If you established good relations with Customer and delivery successful and approved by Customer POC, you will be kick-off of the project because at this moment huge amount of your Chinese co-workers will try to be in a core team and you will not be necessary (bonus matter) even if after that whole project will collapse. 8. If you done something for Chinese colleague, you should not be surprised that this job finally will be not your success and you will get information that 100% of this work was done by him/her. 9. Any personal development is not welcome. This is waste of time and resources from Chinese point of view. Did I mention that you are a tool? 10. Any trainings, even internal, or vacations will decrease your personal score of working hours what finally will have an impact on your yearly score. Thera are many regulations that in such cases you will not be able to get higher score than because of many things. 100% working hours is possible only if you will not leave even single working calendar day. 11. Usually you will have in a contract some standard job position without job description â€“ Huawei common is that you will need to do anything is requested and on visit card you will have some strange job positions including VP level (depends on project and Customer). You will need to have even 8-10 different visit cards with your name and different job positions (with base salary level).
cons: Salary â€“ but remember that you must have good negotiations on start. Later on, will not be too many possibilities to increase salary level. If Huawei needs you, you can request 30-50% bigger salary than market average and it will be accepted.

pros: High Compensation, interesting "wolf culture" if you are able to last here. You will travel to China and enjoy great food.

This culture is often referred to at Huawei as â€œwolf culture,â€ It is culture of cheating, lying, stealing Intellectual Property, stealing designs from one another. "Kill or be killed" High level US employees are hired to steal US Intellectual Property. They will tell you that it is not a case during an interview. 2-3 weeks on the jobs you will be threatened with job loss if you do not provide product design of your previous employer. Once they have all they need you will be promptly terminated. People work here 1-3 years. It is most unethical company I ever worked for. pros: Salary is always on time and competitive.
cons: Management is reserved for Chinese expats, who inhabit their positions for a fixed period. Direct communication manners are similar to military drill seargents, if there is any direct communication at all. Finance department is a mess. Staff and candidates have to fight for their reimbursements. No respect for private live. Employees have to be reachable 24/7, literally. Extra hours are not being reimbursed, but expected. Flexible working hours mean come earlier and go later. No home office. No consistency on all levels. Every day every task is basis for negotiation. The list goes on and on.

review_title: This is worst global corporation I have ever work so far. Don't go there if you are non-Chinese.
pros: The only one benefit to be Huawei employee is base salary - a bit better then offered by competitors. Reason - European employee are not happy to work for Chinese being paid by average salary. Be aware this might be not valid any more: due shrinking Huawei global market and profit in percentage you should expect to be a cheap outsourced employee, not a real employee which may get yearly bonus as well as.
cons: 1. Non Chinese don't have any single chance for development to improve your career. There is no valuable trainings at all available, these a little bit valuable are only in Chines. That makes you are getting quickly behind everyone on the market at technology goes fast. 2. There is no relationship between your work efficiency and your bonus. Doesn't matter how you work bonus will be paid mostly to Chinese. Exceptional non-Chinese might receive valuable bonus. I knew only one such person while I have worked for Huawei. 3. There is no work life balance at all. You must at work between 9.00AM and 9.00PM including Saturdays as well as if you want to be treated well. Otherwise you are just a non-Chinese tool or face for the customer with no future in the corporation. Also you Chinese colleagues will be nice and smile to you if you will do their work. There is no any chance Chinese employee will help you later. It does not pay off for them at all. Business trips - no credit cards, no cash in advance. You must cover everything by yourself in advance (accommodation, meal, even flights), then have a hope your expenses will be refunded in less than 1 month. That means you may wait for your money back even up to three months. You simply offer a free mortgage to your Chinese employer all the time :) 4. Management 111% in Chinese style. That means there is no management in terms of Western standards. You will never know what your manager think about you or what you done not properly or what you should do. 5. Culture and values - Chinese only. Forget about any team night-out, any team mates meetings after work. Chinese (more then half of company) do spend its time only with Chinese. There is a Chinese Great Wall between Chinese and non-Chinese.

review_title: For people who want to learn, excel and be proactive
pros: I worked for Huawei Technologies of Venezuela for 4 years, through an outsourcing contractor, in the Systems Control Center of Movistar Telefonica Venezuela. It was a really rewarding experience. Huawei gave me many opportunities to learn more and more in my professional Networking area. Unfortunately the political and economic situation in my country truncated this successful relationship. Many economic incentives to achieve goals, which favored competition within the group members. I was encouraged and helped to exploit my ability to coordinate activities of the group I was in charge of, and to use my creativity to be more managerial and less operative. Those years with Huawei were hard work, sometimes with almost 72-hour shifts with very few hours of rest, but no one complained because the work was exciting and challenging. I do not know if in other countries Huawei works in the same way, but I have to say that this is a job for people capable of managing stress, who wants to be challenged daily and feel satisfied to have achieved it.
cons: By working in a third party, you do not receive all the benefits of Huawei employees.

review_title: Software engineering at Huawei's Shenzhen offices.
pros: Huawei has generally good management. They have many interesting projects, and good cooperation between teams. We had many training opportunities, and also many opportunities to train our colleagues. Although there are too many employees to get to know everyone: there is a very friendly and sociable atmosphere. I also enjoyed the regular social activities: which included team dinners, a badminton tournament, and regular trips to climb mountains.
cons: Huawei's stringent security policy sometimes made it difficult to obtain job-relevant information. There was little spare office space: so it was often necessary to change office, sometimes with insufficient notice to collect notes and belongings from where we'd been working the previous day.

review_title: You may as well just bash your head against the wall

If travelling on business the budget for hotels is very low so you have to stay in rubbish accommodation. Chinese travelling on business are expected to stay in hostels. Zero flexibility on work location. Do not have a policy to cover travel inoculations, they expect you to pay yourself for your own safety on their business trips. The attitude is work comes before family. I could go on and on.....be warned working here will damage your health and you will at some point think 'how does this company make so much money'.

review_title: No Raise. Management style is to frustrate employees.
pros: None that I know about.
cons: No raise in 4 years. Huawei keeps you at the same salary you were hired at. No opportunity for growth. No grooming. No training. No investment on employees; they are treated as disposable commodities instead of its assets. Everyone is your manager and no one is your manager. Everyone becomes a manager if something is to be asked of you. You will however keep chasing ghosts if you need someone to get you your due from Huawei. I have been kept at the same pay for four years now. When I ask the bosses about it they start talking about Huawei in third person. Listing their own complaints regarding Huawei. As if they are not even Huawei's employees. Huawei management style can best be described as a game of shadows. Which helps Huawei to frustrate its employees when they they have to talk about their issues/benefits. And this is the concensus observation of all our colleagues regarding Huawei throughout Saudi Arabia.

review_title: Good: Lots of opportunity to code. Bad: No work life balance
pros: 1. Job Security: No firing culture. #1 in Telecom business and #3 in Smartphone. 2. Good Pay: Annual package may not wow you, but if you end up among Top Performers then you can make up for it with your bonus and you can get good hikes. 3. Work: Lots of code to write. People here with 1 years experience here know and have done more things than people with 3-5 years experience in service based companies. 4. Learning: Even though company does not directly invest on anyone's learning, since you get to work on some problem from ground-up, you tend to learn a lot. 5. Work Culture: Can come to office in casuals. 6. Onsite Opportunity: If you stick around you will definitely get to travel to China. If you end up in a support job, then you can travel to Mexico, Africa or Europe[less].
cons: 1. Work-life Balance: 12 hours per day is the norm. You will end up working in many Saturdays and holidays. Ask anyone who left Huawei, they will invariable say this was the main reason. 2. Growth: Decisions are usually taken in HQ. From India you can only implement a solution, no real scope for designing it. So you may not find the kind of work appropriate for your level of experience. 3. Pay: Used to be very good in this area, but now there is so much cost cutting going on. Many companies can now match/exceed it. 4. Work Culture: Punch in times are very strict. Being late can lead to loss of pay. 5. Learning: There is no real training. You learn on your own from your own mistakes.

review_title: Exploitation thy name is Huawei Saudi Arabia. No increment in 5 years.
pros: If you want to learn how to exploit those dependent on you for their bread & butter you should join Huawei Saudi Arabia. I don't see any other pro(s) in working with Huawei Saudi Arabia.
cons: Telecome Industry in Saudi Arabia has been hostage to a parasite named Huawei for some time now. It entraps operators and defeats competitors with attractive rates, and is then willing to suck the last drop of blood out of its employees to compensate for their cheaper rates. Those employed directly have plenty to complain about, but those of us who have been hired through sub-contractors are dealt with by Huawei Saudi Arabia in ways renowned slavers of the yore would be proud of. I had been hired 5 years back on a sub-par salary. I had joined it then partly because I was desperate, and the job-market was volatile in Saudi Arabia (it has been volatile for quite a few years now). And partly in the hope that in due time, with increments I will get there. I had recevied assuarances of increment, in due time, from the lower level management too of . However, with the passage of time I realised that I had made a blunder. Despite having received excellent evaluation marks/grades from my superiors over the last 5 years, I have yet to see an increment; not a single penny. The system is so messed up, that new comers who joined our team this year, without any prior experience, are getting more than us who joined 5 years ago. What left me hopeless is that two other colleagues of mine, who joined an year before me, have not had any increment in 6 years. One of them resigned this year for this very reason and went back to his home-country. I too, am now actively looking for another job. So before joining Huawei Saudi Arabia, make sure that you have negotiated a compensation amount that you should be comfortable with for a long long time. Otherwise you'll rue the day you joined Huawei Saudi Arabia, like me.

review_title: DO NOT WORK FOR THIS COMPANY
pros: Great Benefits, nice desk, clean windows. .. yep thats it, nothing else.
cons: Management is terrible. If you are not asian you will never get promoted or treated fairly. The c-level people were all asian and wanted to run the enterprise business in america like they did in china, cutting peoples pay, cutting benefits, cutting everything. I was part of the sales team and they changed the comp plan every quarter making it impossible for me to make comission. They provided no training, no plan, no guidance to achieve my goals. Traveling was a joke. Our budget for meals a day was $40 and hotels was $90 a day. When I did travel some nights I could barely afford motel6. This company is so cheap that they don't even offer coffee. Only water. They never celebrated anything. If you were non-asian you were looked down at. They spoke Mandarin all though out the office extremely loud and it sounded like a 3rd world country call center, and when your on the phones trying to make sales, its impossible with all the foreign language and shouting. Don't expect anyone in HR to help you with anything or payroll, you get the run around all the time. One month our medical got cancelled because they forgot to pay their premium so everyone lost their medical benefits and had to re-enroll. Turn over is extremely high because they are so un-organized and treat their employess so unfairly. Again, if your not asian dont expect anything out of them because they discrimiate against a lot of people within the company. They have actually been sewed on numerious occasions because of this.

review_title: Run, dont walk away from this company
pros: None. Initial salary is attractive.
cons: Futurewei Santa Clara exists only to repatriate Chinese American engineers. In US, >85% of workforce is chinese. Most conversations are in Chinese which creates cultural and language barriers. All decisions and flows are micromanaged by mainland headquarters. No products are produced for North America. No leadership only follower behavior. All programs are offshored within 2 years of being started. All documents are encrypted and time out within months. All design flows are obsoled by HQ. You clearly feel like you work for a China only company. There is a China first mantra and the company exists to provide access to silicon valley. However no projects are adaquetely resourced, only chinese engineers are encouraged and all employees turn over after 5 years. All projects are bid to win, unresourced, required to work with China teams, told thet are overpriced and underperform. No information is shared on requirements or usage, making it difficult to optimize systems. Nightly meetings with mainland staff and frequent trips to mainland are the norm. Benefits (medical, etc) are marginal. If you dont speak the language you are at a severe disadvantage. Constant turnover of management and staff. Missions are not long term. Constant project justification and status instead of empowering teams.

pros: 1. Pay is good 2. HR is helpful
cons: 1. DO NOT join this company in USA, especially if you are on H1B. They have a history of hiring people and firing them once the project is done. If you are on H1B, it can jeopardize your career. For GC and US Citizens, only reason you can work for this company is if they pay you well above the market compensation levels, but even then it is not worth it because of reasons stated below. Many companies are paying similar and not abusing their employees. 2. Poor Management. No peer technical discussion. Managers will ask you to create a project plan assuming multiple resources available. Then they will not provide the resource, and use the project plan that you created to track you back, under totally unrealistic deadlines. Managers will provide wrong directions and hold you responsible for their incorrect decision making. 3. Lack of work ethics/decorum: Managers will pretend that they are doing you a favor by paying you more than people employed in China. They openly say in meetings that â€œyou are paid 5x compared to Chinese employees so you should work 5x moreâ€. No effort estimate will be done for the work. You will go to meetings and they will review the items not done and humiliate you for what is not done. Again, I have been told, â€œI donâ€™t care how it will be done or how many hours is needed, it needs to be done in 2 daysâ€. They will formally track your progress against an unrealistic schedule, probably because they would need this documentation for legal purposes when people are fired 4. Lack of power in US: Most decisions are made in China HQ. So your manager will blame you if your group missed a bug. Everyone higher up blames people down the hierarchy to save their jobs . Your manager will expose your weakness and hide your strength, so that if some thing wrong happens, they can blame and fire you while retaining their own job. This is true whether you are a manager or an employee. 5. Poor infrastructure: IT infrastructure is poor. Compute resource is limited. Too much restriction in accessing documents etc causes loss in productivity. 6. Zero Training: Forget about training sessions. You will not learn anything because there are no training videos, poor documentation and even zero discussion. 7. Competition over co-operation: Managers here promote a culture of competition over co-operation. China folks donâ€™t trust US folks and vice versa. Everyone in US wants to be manager, no one wants to work 8. Communication problem + time zone issues: You will have to work with China folks starting from 7pm. Most of them donâ€™t understand English properly 9. Lack of diversity: Practically zero female engineers and less than 10% non-chinese people 10. Cafeteria: food sucks

review_title: Business culture and ways of working for non Chinese employees
pros: Compensation and reward is 15 to 20% higher than similar roles elsewhere. Working for a large growing technology company. Friendly colleagues and a "can do" collaborative attitude to work.
cons: This is a large global international Chinese company rather than a true global multinational enterprise and there is very little appetite for change. The environment is uncompromisingly Chinese, HQ centric and there is little support provided to non Chinese employees to enable them to carry out their roles effectively. I have worked for global MNE's for 20 years as a professional subject matter expert but was completely unprepared and unsuited for the working environment at Huawei. The internal language is Chinese and the standard of business English, both written and spoken, is very poor making it difficult for non Chinese speaking employees to understand what is required from them or to engage meaningfully with Chinese colleagues on technical issues. The lack of Chinese language skills meant I was unable to carry out my role effectively despite having the requisite technical knowledge and experience. Huawei boasts that 70% of its UK employees are locally hired, which may be the case, but predominantly this is from the local Chinese community for all roles except those which require specific professional skills or expertise. In my opinion it does not provide a suitable work environment for non Chinese employees unless they are prepared to accept a very heirarchical business culture and way of working where everyone is expected to follow globally defined processes to the letter and accept that compliance with these processes will be assessed, measured, audited, scored and ultimately rewarded or punished. There is no trust between HQ and internationally based employees. There is a total lack of autonomy for locally hired staff no matter how senior or expert they are. Subject matter experts are regarded as internal consultants rather than business decision makers. All business decisions are made between Chinese local management and HQ in China and all discussions and meetings are conducted in Chinese with little or no opportunity for the non Chinese staff to participate. I am used to a significant amount of autonomy when carrying out my specialist role coupled with the ability to contribute opinions, ideas and experience to influence ways of working in my functional organisation both locally and globally. I was told that this was one of the main reasons I was being hired but ultimately this did not come to fruition. It was clear that I was to have no opportunity to contribute or influence global processes beyond an initial "knowledge dump" of the ways of working of my previous employer who was a competitor of Huawei. I was there to be harvested of the knowledge I had in my head and once this had occurred I was "put out in the field" to work. Huawei are happy to buy a stable of racehorses and put them to work pulling ploughs every day.

review_title: Anything But An Equal Opportunity Employer
pros: Biggest brand in the market Pay is good, way above average Locations tend to be very good worldwide Attracted a lot of Cisco's previous employees due to their recent lay off, so some smart people there
cons: Let's start with a previous review stating that Huawei is an equal opportunity employer. Whoever wrote that probably is now struggling to hire talents for the company so he/she had to say nice things about this company... All recruitment plans are controlled by the HQ in China, and they are the most racist, sexist, and ageist I've ever encountered in my career. Denying any application of colored people has been their usual practice even in London and Santa Clara. There are some Indians working here in Santa Clara, but they are trying very hard to hire as few as possible going forward. Local Chinese who work in HQ are very good at playing a game called: 'ohhh I'm so busy this job is killing me but first, let me take a 2 hour nap after lunch. ' If you want to know the full picture of what locals they tend to hire, go to Quora. Sadly, they're also the ones more valued by the company. If you're younger than 40, and still aspired to make a career for yourself, do not join this company. If you're older than 40, providing for a family of 4-5, income matters a lot and you don't mind office politics in a Chinese company, and good at being a 'yes-man', then might as well. After all, the pay is alright. Although be aware, they also can find any reason to fire you in a blink of an eye.
